bestBHT.bht: Jesus sat on the mountain, a picturesque scene of repose, with his disciples. From this elevated position on the eastern side of the lake, he observed the multitude approaching, as he had purposely sought out this hill country for rest, prayer, and instruction. Jesus, led by the hand of God, teaches us to align our plans with God's sovereign control, acknowledging that he is above us and orders everything according to his pleasure, even when outcomes differ from our expectations.

Henry Alford: The mountain, perhaps ‘the hill country’ on the shore of the lake.
Expressed in Matthew by 'a desert place apart.'
For this is the only portion of the Galilæan Ministry related by him.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: that hilly range which skirts the east side of the lake.
Marvin Vincent: A mountain [το ορος] . Strictly, the mountain. The writer speaks as one familiar with the district.
He sat [εκθητο] . Imperfect : was sitting, when he saw the multitude approaching (ver. 5).
John Calvin: Such was undoubtedly the purpose which he formed as man; but the purpose of God was different, which he willingly obeyed.
Although, therefore, he avoided the sight of men, yet he permits himself to be led by the hand of God as into a crowded theater.

We are therefore taught by this example to form our plans in conformity to the course of events, but in such a manner that, if the result be different from what we expected, we may not be displeased that God is above us, and regulates everything according to his pleasure.
Philip Schaff: He retired for the purpose of rest and prayer, and that he might instruct his disciples."
'The mountain' we must probably understand in a general sense as meaning the high ground near Bethsaida.
In this part the eastern hills closely approach the lake.
Archibald T. Robertson: From the level of the Jordan valley up into the high hill on the eastern side."
After the miracle Jesus went further up into the mountain to pray.
John Gill: And Jesus went up into a mountain... and there he sat with his disciples...
John Wesley: Jesus went up — Before the people overtook him.

bhtAttempts.bht: Jesus was sitting on the mountaintop, taking in the view of the multitude approaching. This hill country, the only part of the Galilean Ministry mentioned by Matthew, provided a peaceful backdrop for Jesus to rest, pray, and instruct his disciples. From this vantage point, high above the Jordan valley, Jesus planned his actions in accordance with God's will. Although his intentions may have been different from God's, Jesus willingly obeyed and allowed himself to be led by God's hand. This serves as a reminder for us to form our plans in alignment with God's sovereign control, knowing that he orchestrates everything according to his purposes.

Jesus was sitting on the mountaintop, taking in the view of the multitude approaching. From this high ground near Bethsaida, he planned his actions in accordance with God's will. Although his intentions may have been different, Jesus willingly obeyed and allowed himself to be led by God. This serves as a reminder for us to form our plans in alignment with God's sovereign control, knowing that he orchestrates everything according to his purposes.

Jesus sat on the mountain, a picturesque scene of repose, with his disciples. From this elevated position on the eastern side of the lake, he observed the multitude approaching, as he had purposely sought out this hill country for rest, prayer, and instruction. Jesus, led by the hand of God, teaches us to align our plans with God's sovereign control, acknowledging that he is above us and orders everything according to his pleasure, even when outcomes differ from our expectations.

From this elevated position, he observed the multitude approaching, as he had purposely sought out this hill country for rest, prayer, and instruction. Jesus, led by the hand of God, teaches us to align our plans with God's control, knowing that he orders everything according to his pleasure, even when outcomes differ from our expectations.

Jesus sat on the mountain, a picture of repose, with his disciples as the multitude approached. This hill country, possibly the high ground near Bethsaida, provided a peaceful place for Jesus to rest, pray, and instruct his followers. From this vantage point, elevated above the Jordan valley, Jesus formed his plans in alignment with God's will, willingly obeying and allowing himself to be led by God's hand. This serves as a reminder for us to align our plans with God's sovereign control, trusting that he orchestrates everything according to his purposes.
